content: quote: Ireland Where they come from: Africa, South Asia, Eastern Europe Immigrants as percentage of population: 14 percent Why they’re welcome:There’s enough wealth to go around. Known primarily as a source of immigrants throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, the “Celtic Tiger” economic boom of the last decade and the resulting prosperity have now made the Emerald Isle an attractive destination. Ireland is also unique in the political rights it grants to noncitizens, which include voting, joining the police force, and running for local office. In the Dublin suburb of Portlaoise last summer, Nigerian-born Rotimi Adebari was elected as Ireland’s first black mayor. Although a few incidents of racial harassment have been reported, the backlash has been minimal, and Ireland doesn’t have the far-right nationalist parties that are common throughout the rest of Europe. Spain Where they come from: North Africa, Latin America Immigrants as percentage of population: 11 percent Why they’re welcome: It’s all about the growth. Like Ireland, Spain spent decades as an economic basket case, but it is now one of Europe’s best-performing economies, thanks largely to its open-door immigration policy, instituted in the late 1990s. Spain has absorbed more than 3 million immigrants, and 11 percent of its population is now foreign-born. Many are attracted by Spain’s thriving construction sector, and minimum-wage agriculture and service jobs are increasingly filled by immigrants. Despite some fears provoked by the 2004 Madrid train bombings, carried out in part by Moroccan immigrants, Spain is keeping the door open and responded to its illegal-immigration problem with a large-scale amnesty in 2005. It’s not all good news for immigrants, though. Human Rights Watch blasted the Spanish government last summer for mistreating African migrant children at its Canary Islands detention centers. Canada Where they come from: East Asia, South Asia Immigrants as percentage of population: 19 percent Why they’re welcome: The country is running out of workers. Canada’s finance minister recently said that population and labor shortages are Canada’s most pressing economic challenges. One out of 7 Canadians is now a senior citizen, and the country’s fertility rate has been below replacement level since the early 1970s. In response, lawmakers in Ottawa are considering enhancing Canada’s immigration laws, which are already among the world’s most liberal. Canada has accepted around 200,000 immigrants per year over the last 10 years. Canada is also known for having a remarkably open policy for asylum seekers and accepts nearly half of those who seek refugee status. (The United States accepts less than a third.) Security concerns since 9/11 have led Canada to beef up security along its southern border and increase police surveillance powers, but these measures have not led to a decrease in immigration. Israel Where they come from: North America, the former Soviet Union Immigrants as percentage of population: 40 percent Why they’re welcome:Because Israel wants to remain a Jewish state. Yasir Arafat had a point when he remarked that the Palestinians’ greatest weapon is the womb. The Gaza Strip, for instance, has one of the world’s fastest-growing populations. Meanwhile, Israel’s Jewish birthrate has remained stagnant, and increasingly large numbers of young Israelis choose to emigrate as violence continues. In response, Jewish nonprofit organizations are working to entice Jews from around the world to the Holy Land, even offering grants of $3,000 to $10,000 as an incentive. Under Israeli law, Jews are automatically granted citizenship. These measures may be working. The year 2006 saw the first upswing in immigration from the United States in years. Most of Israel’s new arrivals, however, are from former Soviet bloc countries, and many have only tenuous connections to Judaism. The Knesset even debated amending the “law of return” policy last year when police broke up a neo-Nazi group in the city of Petah Tikva. New Zealand Where they come from: East Asia and the Pacific Islands Immigrants as percentage of population: 16 percent Why they’re welcome:Because New Zealand wants the best. In how many countries can you imagine a politician saying, “We are in a global race for talent and we must win our share,” as New Zealand’s then immigration minister did in 2005? For New Zealand, immigration is all about skills. Applicants are awarded a score based on their level of occupational ability. Those scoring above a certain level are automatically granted entrance. With high levels of economic growth and a low population, New Zealand’s policies are geared toward shoring up key sectors of the country’s economy. On the whole, immigrants are thriving in New Zealand’s economic boom and receive public assistance at a lower level than the population at large. The good times may not last forever, though. Nationalist politicians routinely grumble about how the influx of Asian immigrants is changing the country’s demographic makeup, and the government is gradually raising language and skill requirements. Bit dated, but still interesting report! +http://www.foreignpolicy.com/story/cms.php?story_id=4185

title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: After living in Ireland for 4 years since 02 and making numerous trips back and forth, you best delete Ireland from that list. Ireland was the first to go into recession, immigrants are now leaving because they aren't getting the same social welfare, their health coverage is all depleted. The so-called "Celtic Tiger" has up and bit them in their asses. It's their fault, no one elses. When, what we call, a garden shed sells for over $200,000 dollars, they deserve a recession. Anyone that goes there with the "Quiet Man Syndrome" has a real shock awaiting them. The article is way way way out of date.
reply: After living in Ireland for 4 years since 02 and making numerous trips back and forth, you best delete Ireland from that list. Anyone that goes there with the "Quiet Man Syndrome" has a real shock awaiting them. The article is way way way out of date.
title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: Canada's still the land of dreams for many. But lately eastern Europeans are 'big' on us. A newspaper reported to-day that virtually all the Gypsies (Roma) in the former Czechoslovakia were applying for refugee status. Refugees do quite well in Canada, picking up welare and paid benefits well in excess of the average pensioner. Three years and they're citizens with a vested 'old age pension' able to 'sponsor' the family. Medical is paid from the first day in subsidized housing, that's paid too.
reply: Canada's still the land of dreams for many. But lately eastern Europeans are 'big' on us. Three years and they're citizens with a vested 'old age pension' able to 'sponsor' the family. Medical is paid from the first day in subsidized housing, that's paid too.
title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: The Siggie has a point. Ireland's economy is very dodgy at the moment, we're even getting Eastern European immigrants stopping off in Britain for a while on their way back to Poland and points East - and our economy is pretty much stuffed. One can traditionally gauge the state of the Irish economy by the number of people who've crossed the Irish Sea for the National Hunt Festival at Cheltenham. This year it is apparently possible to find a room in a hotel or b&b within twenty miles of the course and sales of Guinness are down, this despite the Irish getting first, second and third in the cross-country race and the winner of the the Arkle.
reply: The Siggie has a point. title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: SignalsgtWilliams is right on. Ireland is no longer a place where one can go and hope to live a peaceful quiet retirement. A nice two bedroom, two bathroom house will cost you well over $200,000 and good luck with medical, dental, and other things we take for granted here in the states.

Funny it doesn't have about the spike in crime in Ireland, rising resentment of immigrants(both instances toward Eastern Europeans). It's not just crime against immigrants, they have their own cartel. Drive by shootings in Limerick and Cork are quite common. East, North and South St Louis has nothing on Dublin, Cork or Limerick. As for health care, crap!!!!! While I was there on the news, a man bled to death internally while on a gurney, in the hallway with his family around him over six hours waiting for assistance. Health Minister Carney, OH!!! WELL!!! And I like to know where in Ireland anyone could find a two bedroom and two bath home for $200,000 dollars, rent for a one bedroom, on average is over $1300. a month. When a pint of Guenness cost more in Dublin than in Paris, the irish are recieving exactly what they planted. We are talking about Ireland, the Republic of, not Northern Ireland where the troubles have returned. This is a spinter IRA group, radicals that are found most anywhere.

Known primarily as a source of immigrants throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, the “Celtic Tiger” economic boom of the last decade and the resulting prosperity have now made the Emerald Isle an attractive destination. Ireland is also unique in the political rights it grants to noncitizens, which include voting, joining the police force, and running for local office. In the Dublin suburb of Portlaoise last summer, Nigerian-born Rotimi Adebari was elected as Ireland’s first black mayor. Although a few incidents of racial harassment have been reported, the backlash has been minimal, and Ireland doesn’t have the far-right nationalist parties that are common throughout the rest of Europe. Funny it doesn't have about the spike in crime in Ireland, rising resentment of immigrants(both instances toward Eastern Europeans).
reply: It's not just crime against immigrants, they have their own cartel. Drive by shootings in Limerick and Cork are quite common. East, North and South St Louis has nothing on Dublin, Cork or Limerick. As for health care, crap!!!!! While I was there on the news, a man bled to death internally while on a gurney, in the hallway with his family around him over six hours waiting for assistance. Health Minister Carney, OH!!! WELL!!! And I like to know where in Ireland anyone could find a two bedroom and two bath home for $200,000 dollars, rent for a one bedroom, on average is over $1300. a month. When a pint of Guenness cost more in Dublin than in Paris, the irish are recieving exactly what they planted. We are talking about Ireland, the Republic of, not Northern Ireland where the troubles have returned. This is a spinter IRA group, radicals that are found most anywhere.
title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: Celtic Tiger? WTF? better read the Irish Echo boyo..... Ireland's (ROI, not NI)Economy was headed downwards for sometime before the US financial disaster. While Illegal Immigrants may have a Support network there, it is on the backs of an Irish Public that can barely support itself now. not to mention the crime it brought in, the racist counterreaction, you can expect that the Irish man in the street isnt to thrilled to be an asylum paradise anymore.

title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: quote: Ireland Where they come from: Africa, South Asia, Eastern Europe Immigrants as percentage of population: 14 percent Why they’re welcome:There’s enough wealth to go around. Known primarily as a source of immigrants throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, the “Celtic Tiger” economic boom of the last decade and the resulting prosperity have now made the Emerald Isle an attractive destination. Ireland is also unique in the political rights it grants to noncitizens, which include voting, joining the police force, and running for local office. In the Dublin suburb of Portlaoise last summer, Nigerian-born Rotimi Adebari was elected as Ireland’s first black mayor. Although a few incidents of racial harassment have been reported, the backlash has been minimal, and Ireland doesn’t have the far-right nationalist parties that are common throughout the rest of Europe. Spain Where they come from: North Africa, Latin America Immigrants as percentage of population: 11 percent Why they’re welcome: It’s all about the growth. Like Ireland, Spain spent decades as an economic basket case, but it is now one of Europe’s best-performing economies, thanks largely to its open-door immigration policy, instituted in the late 1990s. Spain has absorbed more than 3 million immigrants, and 11 percent of its population is now foreign-born. Many are attracted by Spain’s thriving construction sector, and minimum-wage agriculture and service jobs are increasingly filled by immigrants. Despite some fears provoked by the 2004 Madrid train bombings, carried out in part by Moroccan immigrants, Spain is keeping the door open and responded to its illegal-immigration problem with a large-scale amnesty in 2005. It’s not all good news for immigrants, though. Human Rights Watch blasted the Spanish government last summer for mistreating African migrant children at its Canary Islands detention centers. Canada Where they come from: East Asia, South Asia Immigrants as percentage of population: 19 percent Why they’re welcome: The country is running out of workers. Canada’s finance minister recently said that population and labor shortages are Canada’s most pressing economic challenges. One out of 7 Canadians is now a senior citizen, and the country’s fertility rate has been below replacement level since the early 1970s. In response, lawmakers in Ottawa are considering enhancing Canada’s immigration laws, which are already among the world’s most liberal. Canada has accepted around 200,000 immigrants per year over the last 10 years. Canada is also known for having a remarkably open policy for asylum seekers and accepts nearly half of those who seek refugee status. (The United States accepts less than a third.) Security concerns since 9/11 have led Canada to beef up security along its southern border and increase police surveillance powers, but these measures have not led to a decrease in immigration. Israel Where they come from: North America, the former Soviet Union Immigrants as percentage of population: 40 percent Why they’re welcome:Because Israel wants to remain a Jewish state. Yasir Arafat had a point when he remarked that the Palestinians’ greatest weapon is the womb. The Gaza Strip, for instance, has one of the world’s fastest-growing populations. Meanwhile, Israel’s Jewish birthrate has remained stagnant, and increasingly large numbers of young Israelis choose to emigrate as violence continues. In response, Jewish nonprofit organizations are working to entice Jews from around the world to the Holy Land, even offering grants of $3,000 to $10,000 as an incentive. Under Israeli law, Jews are automatically granted citizenship. These measures may be working. The year 2006 saw the first upswing in immigration from the United States in years. Most of Israel’s new arrivals, however, are from former Soviet bloc countries, and many have only tenuous connections to Judaism. The Knesset even debated amending the “law of return” policy last year when police broke up a neo-Nazi group in the city of Petah Tikva. New Zealand Where they come from: East Asia and the Pacific Islands Immigrants as percentage of population: 16 percent Why they’re welcome:Because New Zealand wants the best. In how many countries can you imagine a politician saying, “We are in a global race for talent and we must win our share,” as New Zealand’s then immigration minister did in 2005? For New Zealand, immigration is all about skills. Applicants are awarded a score based on their level of occupational ability. Those scoring above a certain level are automatically granted entrance. With high levels of economic growth and a low population, New Zealand’s policies are geared toward shoring up key sectors of the country’s economy. On the whole, immigrants are thriving in New Zealand’s economic boom and receive public assistance at a lower level than the population at large. The good times may not last forever, though. Nationalist politicians routinely grumble about how the influx of Asian immigrants is changing the country’s demographic makeup, and the government is gradually raising language and skill requirements. Bit dated, but still interesting report! +http://www.foreignpolicy.com/story/cms.php?story_id=4185

content: After living in Ireland for 4 years since 02 and making numerous trips back and forth, you best delete Ireland from that list. Ireland was the first to go into recession, immigrants are now leaving because they aren't getting the same social welfare, their health coverage is all depleted. The so-called "Celtic Tiger" has up and bit them in their asses. It's their fault, no one elses. When, what we call, a garden shed sells for over $200,000 dollars, they deserve a recession. Anyone that goes there with the "Quiet Man Syndrome" has a real shock awaiting them. The article is way way way out of date.

title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: Canada's still the land of dreams for many. But lately eastern Europeans are 'big' on us. A newspaper reported to-day that virtually all the Gypsies (Roma) in the former Czechoslovakia were applying for refugee status. Refugees do quite well in Canada, picking up welare and paid benefits well in excess of the average pensioner. Three years and they're citizens with a vested 'old age pension' able to 'sponsor' the family. Medical is paid from the first day in subsidized housing, that's paid too.

Three years and they're citizens with a vested 'old age pension' able to 'sponsor' the family. Medical is paid from the first day in subsidized housing, that's paid too.
title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: The Siggie has a point. Ireland's economy is very dodgy at the moment, we're even getting Eastern European immigrants stopping off in Britain for a while on their way back to Poland and points East - and our economy is pretty much stuffed. One can traditionally gauge the state of the Irish economy by the number of people who've crossed the Irish Sea for the National Hunt Festival at Cheltenham. This year it is apparently possible to find a room in a hotel or b&b within twenty miles of the course and sales of Guinness are down, this despite the Irish getting first, second and third in the cross-country race and the winner of the the Arkle.

title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: SignalsgtWilliams is right on. Ireland is no longer a place where one can go and hope to live a peaceful quiet retirement. A nice two bedroom, two bathroom house will cost you well over $200,000 and good luck with medical, dental, and other things we take for granted here in the states.

title: The List: The World’s Best Places to Be an Immigrant

content: quote: Originally posted by Knele: [QUOTE] Ireland Where they come from: Africa, South Asia, Eastern Europe Immigrants as percentage of population: 14 percent Why they’re welcome:There’s enough wealth to go around. Known primarily as a source of immigrants throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, the “Celtic Tiger” economic boom of the last decade and the resulting prosperity have now made the Emerald Isle an attractive destination. Ireland is also unique in the political rights it grants to noncitizens, which include voting, joining the police force, and running for local office. In the Dublin suburb of Portlaoise last summer, Nigerian-born Rotimi Adebari was elected as Ireland’s first black mayor. Although a few incidents of racial harassment have been reported, the backlash has been minimal, and Ireland doesn’t have the far-right nationalist parties that are common throughout the rest of Europe. Funny it doesn't have about the spike in crime in Ireland, rising resentment of immigrants(both instances toward Eastern Europeans).
quote: Originally posted by Knele: [QUOTE] Ireland Where they come from: Africa, South Asia, Eastern Europe Immigrants as percentage of population: 14 percent Why they’re welcome:There’s enough wealth to go around. Although a few incidents of racial harassment have been reported, the backlash has been minimal, and Ireland doesn’t have the far-right nationalist parties that are common throughout the rest of Europe.
reply: Funny it doesn't have about the spike in crime in Ireland, rising resentment of immigrants(both instances toward Eastern Europeans).

It's not just crime against immigrants, they have their own cartel. Drive by shootings in Limerick and Cork are quite common. East, North and South St Louis has nothing on Dublin, Cork or Limerick. As for health care, crap!!!!! While I was there on the news, a man bled to death internally while on a gurney, in the hallway with his family around him over six hours waiting for assistance. Health Minister Carney, OH!!! WELL!!! And I like to know where in Ireland anyone could find a two bedroom and two bath home for $200,000 dollars, rent for a one bedroom, on average is over $1300. a month. When a pint of Guenness cost more in Dublin than in Paris, the irish are recieving exactly what they planted. We are talking about Ireland, the Republic of, not Northern Ireland where the troubles have returned. This is a spinter IRA group, radicals that are found most anywhere.

content: Celtic Tiger? WTF? better read the Irish Echo boyo..... Ireland's (ROI, not NI)Economy was headed downwards for sometime before the US financial disaster. While Illegal Immigrants may have a Support network there, it is on the backs of an Irish Public that can barely support itself now. not to mention the crime it brought in, the racist counterreaction, you can expect that the Irish man in the street isnt to thrilled to be an asylum paradise anymore.

I first went over in 1990 when my wife was going through her citizenship process, it's quite a shock in just that relatively short time. I would have loved to have gone over there to live back in 80-85 when you could buy a victorian mansion for a couple of thousands. That was the last time there were flights and ferries leaving hourly for the irish looking for work. It is truely a cultural shock today. The Celtic Tiger started around 95.
